title: Univers vs Utah
content:
Am I seeing things or are these two awfully similar ?

[Univers](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313/http:/www.linotype.com/12641/univers55roman-font.html):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313im_/http:/typophile.com/files/univers_5054.png)

[Utah](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313/http:/www.linotype.com/522370/utahwgl-font.html):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313im_/http:/typophile.com/files/utah_6369.png)

Not _identical_ as there are some minute differences as in lowercase 'n', but still...
author: apankrat

comments.content:
Where is this lowercase n? Spurs on a, b, g, q seem more 'spurry' but that is hardly a change.

[www.evanmade.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313/http:/evanmade.com/)

When I see a font named after a place, I expect it to be a clone of something else. Apple started it all with their city fonts, and then Corel took it to a whole new level. I'd never name a font after a location.

_Corel took it to a whole new level_

I would have said Bitstream, which called its unlicensed copy Zurich.
According to [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313/http:/www.linotype.com/de/522370/utahwgl-schrift.html) link it says Monotype Design Studio.
Monotype has developed lots of knockoffs over the years. Ever try comparing Palatino with Book Antiqua?

Doesn't "Helvetica" basically mean "Swiss?" Okay, a bit of a stretch.

Nice list Mark!
Helvetia means Swiss. And yeah Mark, there are a lot of legit place fonts. How many of them were created post 1985?
The faces in the list all started in metal (some never went beyond it).
Technically, _Helvetia_ means 'Switzerland' while _Helvetica_ means 'Swiss'. Which raises the question, are place name fonts more legitimate if they are 1. adjectives? 2. Latin? 3. Latin adjectives?
Is [Albany](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313/http:/www.linotype.com/164535/albany-family.html) (also in the "Monotype Originals" series) a takeoff on another font?
Oops: Aachen didn't start out in metal and neither did Berkeley Old Style, although it was based on a metal face which was also named after a place (University of California Old Style).
It seems to me like a Univers version of "helvetica-Arial" parody.
You forgot Gotham Mark. Home of the bat
Yes, of course. I was trying to think of older fonts, before the DTP era, so I'm sure I left out a lot of more recent ones.

Maybe we could introduce a new term for these rip-offs? I would suggest Arial-isation, fonts that have been arialised... Any better ideas? ;-)

greetings Jeffrey  
 [infraordinaire](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124161313/http:/www.infraordinaire.com/wordpress)
